title: 113_s760
content: The "Government Customer Service Improvement Act of 2013" defines terms like "agency" and "customer" and focuses on developing customer service standards. The Government Customer Service Improvement Act of 2013 mandates the development of Government-wide and agency-specific customer service standards, including goals for service improvements and response times for various communication channels and processes. The agency must establish customer service standards aligned with Government-wide standards, to be included in Agency Performance Plans. These standards should cover target call wait times, response times for correspondence, metrics in service agreements, processing times for benefits and payments, and recommendations for effective publication. The Performance Improvement Officer collects customer feedback on agency customer service quality, to be included in performance reports. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget includes agency achievements in meeting customer service standards in annual performance updates. SEC. 4. SERVICE IMPROVEMENT UNIT PILOT PROGRAM. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will establish the Service Improvement Unit Pilot Program to assist agencies not meeting Government-wide standards. Agency heads will detail employees with expertise in change management, process improvement, and IT innovation to work on the program. The program aims to help agencies improve service delivery and develop solutions to meet customer service standards. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will establish a Service Improvement Unit Pilot Program to assist agencies in improving service delivery by evaluating efforts, developing improvement plans, monitoring implementation, and submitting monthly progress reports until customer service standards are met. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress on the pilot program's accomplishments and recommendations for achieving customer service standards. The Administrator of General Services will provide support for implementing the program, and agencies may provide personnel expertise. The pilot program will terminate 2 years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. RETIREMENT REPORTING. In this section, the Director of the Office of Personnel Management must submit monthly reports to Congress and the Comptroller General evaluating the retirement information submitted by agencies. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must report monthly to Congress and the Comptroller General on the status of pending retirement benefit applications, including the number of months each application has been pending. The reporting requirement is suspended for the Director after a 3-year period with no applications pending for more than 60 days. Additionally, the Director must establish a timetable for modernization efforts. The Office of Personnel Management must provide a timetable for the retirement systems modernization project completion and the date for Federal payroll entities to transmit personnel data. The budget request should include progress updates and resource recommendations for the project implementation. Management in each budget request of the Office of Personnel Management submitted for the President's budget to Congress. SEC. 6. NO INCREASE IN EXPENDITURES. Congress believes no extra funds should be allocated for this Act.
